title: Two-way conversations
text:
So far weâ€™ve been very good at talking at our chatbot, but not thinking too much about what it says in return. Itâ€™s just a dumb intern, right? If we were working with a colleague, weâ€™d probably approach things a little differently: even something as simple as â€œwhat do you think?â€ could take our piece in a new direction.
Now itâ€™s time to adjust our mindset to take better advantage of our AI tool. If you start to think of the chatbot as your boss instead of your employee, or your coworker instead of your intern, things get a lot more interesting!




    


Weâ€™re going to combine elements of all of the sections weâ€™ve been through so far:

Long, details prompts
Back-and-forth conversations
Multiple angles or suggestions

The addition weâ€™re making now making our conversations intentional. Previously weâ€™ve only had conversations when things have gone wrong or we want an improvement or correct. This time weâ€™re going to make the conversation the entire point.






A prompt suggestion



Act as an editor of the New York Times. You are going to help me write a headline. It is going to take several steps of a conversational process.
First, ask me for the article. When requested, I will paste it in. Note that it might include image captions, ads, etc. Sorry for not cleaning it up!
Second, provide several options for angles that we can take for the headline and ask if I have a preference. Allow me to select one or provide another another suggestion. If I do neither, assume I want a mix of different angles.
Finally, provide a list of five headlines. Provide suggestions of directions we could take in improvements, and ask if there is anything that is missing or any adjustments that I would like to have made.


Click here to start the conversation ğŸ”®
This is the part that, to me, feels a lot like magic. Your prompt is in some ways guidance to yourself instead of to the machine, and is forcing you to take into account each piece that youâ€™ve decided (through the prompt) is important.
You could add a thousand-and-one other little snippets to the prompt, depending on what you feel is useful.

title: Rule of five
text:
One way to iterate more quickly when using AI tools is the rule of five (or ten, or thirty, or ninety). Instead of asking for one headline at a time, ask ChatGPT for five headlines.
Along with getting more ideas set out in front of you, Iâ€™ve also found it to be helpful process for highlighting bias. I donâ€™t (necessarily) mean what we normally think of as bias - think of it more like â€œhabitsâ€ or â€œtendencies.â€ Maybe one person always writes sensationalist headlines, another person always uses colons and subheads.




    


Weâ€™re going to start from the same headline generation prompt as before, but change it to be for five headlines instead of just one.






A prompt suggestion



You are an editor at the New York Times. Write five headlines for the article below. The tone should be informed but approachable. Limit the headline to 70 characters.
ARTICLE:
(paste the story in)


Click here to use my article ğŸ”®
Clear the chat ğŸ”®
This is simple, this is easy. And nothingâ€™s stopping us from asking for ten headlines or twenty headlines!


The five responses I got were pretty much all in the same vein:


Bronx Drug Market Thrives as City Battles Overdose Crisis
Fentanyl Fear Rises in NYC Amid Record Overdose Deaths
In Bronx Underpass, Open Drug Use and Rising Tensions
Bronx Tragedy: Fentanylâ€™s Shadow Over a Community in Crisis
Amidst Drug Crisis, Bronx Residents Seek Safer Streets


When you ask for five headlines instead of just one, the similarities really jump out at you! Weâ€™re being gently guided into a certain direction, even though the LLM doesnâ€™t actually have a reason to send us in one direction or another (it canâ€™t think, after all!).
I think calling this â€œbiasâ€ is a bit much, but itâ€™s a gentle reminder that AI tools come with baked-in assumptions and angles. If you donâ€™t work hard to notice them, at the very least theyâ€™ll make all your content similar and boring!






Notice how even though I asked ChatGPT to not use subheads or colons, it did anyway! You should expect the AI to ignore your instructions a good portion of the time.



One way to add a little diversity to the mix is to simply ask for it.



An extension of the simple â€œgive us fiveâ€ from above might be to explicitly ask ChatGPT for five markedly different options â€“ in this case it might be five different angles or five different tones.
Even if we arenâ€™t making specific demands of the AI tool on how to break out of its habits, asking for different takes can go a long way in helping it happen.






A prompt suggestion



You are an editor at the New York Times. Write five headlines for the story below. The tone should be informed but approachable. Limit the headline to 70 characters.
Have each headline elicit a different emotional response or subject-matter concern from the reader. Label each headline with the emotion/concern.
ARTICLE:
(paste the story in)


Click here to use my article ğŸ”®
Clear the chat ğŸ”®






Letâ€™s take a look at the results I got:


Concern: Public Safety: â€œBronx Daycare Tragedy Highlights Rampant Drug Crisis in NYCâ€
Emotion: Outrage: â€œFentanyl Scourge Unchecked: Bronx Community Demands Actionâ€
Emotion: Compassion: â€œAmid Bronx Despair, a Plea for Help Against Drug Menaceâ€
Concern: Policy and Governance: â€œNYC Struggles with Drug Policy as Overdoses Soar, Communities Sufferâ€
Emotion: Fear: â€œBronx Nightmare: Fentanyl Threat Looms as Overdoses Riseâ€


When youâ€™re provided suggestions by the AI, itâ€™s easy to just go along with them. But when you starting seeing the habits and tendencies and start asking for different angles, I feel like thatâ€™s when you start to realize â€œhey, weâ€™re giving up a lot of control here!â€
If the media has a certain way of talking about certain topics â€“ which media critics like Alec Karakatsanis would very much agree â€“ it takes a certain degree effort to break out of the typical framing.
Using an AI-generated headline can go both ways: since language models are just statistical predictions of the next word, they go above and beyond when it comes to reinforcing whatâ€™s â€œtypical,â€ or the status quo of how a subject is discussed. But conversely, if we recognize that other angles might exist, itâ€™s easy enough to prompt in directions we wouldnâ€™t normally think about.
In our next step we go even further in having the AI help us generate more headlines and think critically about our angles.

title: Prompting basics: generating headlines
text:
Prompting basics: generating headlines
In this section, weâ€™re going to take a look at the most basic interaction youâ€™ll have with AI: talking to a chatbot!
While this section is technically based around writing headlines with ChatGPT, what youâ€™re going to learn in the process is a lot more general (and useful!). Instead of just headlines, itâ€™s about how you can talk to and use AI during the creative process, a.k.a. â€œprompt engineering.â€

Table of contents
I recommend starting from the beginning and working your way through each section.

Basic prompting, or how to have a conversation with your AI buddy
Prompt Engineering, or getting it right the first time
Rule of five, how to break out of biased results (but no, not that bias)
Two-way conversations, having intentional interactions with your AI boss or coworker
Conclusion

title: The big reveal
text:
But now the important part: comparing the AI-generated headline(s) with the hand-crafted artisinal human-generated ones. How do the suggestions compare with the final headline the NYT used? 1 Letâ€™s take a look:

The actual New York Times headline is far more vague, less fear-inducing, and doesnâ€™t mention the Bronx at all. It makes it a story relevant to all New Yorkers, but doesnâ€™t turn it into fearmongering clickbait.
Honestly, I was shocked: itâ€™s so far from anything that GPT suggested. Maybe your prompts got you closer, but I was certainly not that lucky.


This whole process made me think about a paper comparing story generation between humans and humans assisted by AI: 2
Stories written with AI assitance were scored as better than stories written by humans alone. Despite being worse, though, the human-writtens stories had a much wider range of ideas and concepts in them. AI guidance provided the authors a higher-scoring work, but at the expense of actually being unique!
To abuse a quote: â€œall human work improved by AI is alike; every purely human work is creative in its own way.â€
In future chapters weâ€™ll dig deeper into how AI tools like ChatGPT work, and how a side effect of their construction might mean that headline generation is the only thing theyâ€™re reasonably good at! So whether you were super excited or roundly unimpressed: get excited for a ride down to the bottom.

title: AI Workbook for Journalists
text:
We can all agree that writing headlines is the most horrific thing journalists have to endure. Letâ€™s see what we can do to solve that problem!
Letâ€™s justâ€¦ ask ChatGPT. Easy-peasy.
Your mission has two parts:
The first part is to open up ChatGPT.
The second part is to find a news article that youâ€™d like to have a headline generated for. Itâ€™s important thatâ€™s been published so you can compare the headline thatâ€™s generated to the headline that was actually published.
Iâ€™m going to use this piece about drug use in the Bronx.
Weâ€™ll start by simply asking ChatGPT to generate a headline for us.
**Write a headline for the story below:**

(paste the story in)






The NYT article has ads and pictures and stuff halfway through â€“ instead of selecting the full page of text I had to paste it in a few chunks.



My result says: **This is my result*
Is it good? Is it bad?
I find that using generative AI is a lot like going out to eat: even if something is objectively not wonderful, it seems great since you didnâ€™t have to do the work. I encourage you to be as critical as possible of the results youâ€™re getting back.
Letâ€™s try again, but this time weâ€™ll give a little more guidance:
**You are an editor for the New York Times. Write a headline for the story below. The tone should be informed but approachable. Limit the headline to 70 characters.**

(paste the story in)
Now itâ€™s a bit shorter and the tone has shifted (I think?).
It still isnâ€™t exactly perfect, which means we can try again. And again. And again. Each time nudging the headline in the direction weâ€™re looking for. This is why ChatGPT is perfect for headline generation: itâ€™s an iterative process.
Unlike many other tasks where you want AI to do the entire job without interruption, headlines are both short enough and important enough that you (probably) want to be fully involved from start to finish.
As you change your prompt again and again, you start to note a bit of sameness about the headlines. They all seem to maybe have a similar tone, or a similar angle, or something thatâ€™s justâ€¦ not as varied as when youâ€™d ask a person to generate a handful of headlines.
A way to get to this point faster is the rule of five. Instead of asking for one headline at a time, ask ChatGPT for five headlines.
**You are an editor for the New York Times. Write five headline for the story below. The tone should be informed but approachable. Limit each headline to 70 characters.**

(paste the story in)
Now the similarities really jump out at you! Weâ€™re being gently guided into a certain direction, even if itâ€™s completely by accident.
I think calling this â€œbiasâ€ is a bit much, but itâ€™s a gentle reminder that AI tools come with baked-in assumptions and angles. If you donâ€™t pay attention to or notice them, at the very least theyâ€™ll make your headlines all similar and boring!






Notice how even though I asked ChatGPT to not use subheads or colons, it did anyway! You should expect the AI to ignore your instructions a good portion of the time.



An extension of this approach might be to ask ChatGPT for five different angles, or five different tones.
Write five headlines for the story below. Limit each headline to around twelve words. Have each headline elicit a different emotional response from the reader. Label each headline with the emotion. Headlines should be elegant, and with the tone of the New Yorker. Don't use colons or multi-part headlines.

(paste the story in)
Once weâ€™ve gone this far, weâ€™re probably going to end up picking a variation of one of the headlines that ChatGPT has suggested. But now the important part: how does it compare with the final headline the NYT used?
The NYT one is far more vague, less fear-inducing, and doesnâ€™t mention the Bronx at all. It makes it a story relevant to all New Yorkers, but doesnâ€™t turn it into fearmongering clickbait.
Honestly, I was shocked: itâ€™s so far from anything that GPT suggested.
I read paper a while ago about story generation from humans and humans assisted by AI. Humans alone performed worse on average, but also had a much wider range of ideas and concepts brought into the stories. AI-assisted stories were better, but also more similar to each other. To abuse a quote, â€œall uncreative human work improved by AI is alike; every skilled creative human work is interesting in its own way.â€

title: The value of chatting
text:
We can all agree that writing headlines is the most horrific thing journalists have to endure. Letâ€™s see what we can do to solve that problem!
Start by finding a news article that youâ€™d like to have a headline generated for. Itâ€™s important that the story has been published so you can compare the headline thatâ€™s generated to the headline that was actually published.1
Iâ€™m going to use this piece about drug use in the Bronx. If you donâ€™t have your own story, no worries â€“ youâ€™ll be able to click buttons to use mine instead.






The NYT article has ads and pictures and other non-content partway through. Instead of selecting the full page of text I had to paste it in a few chunks.







    


Once youâ€™ve found an article youâ€™d like to use, weâ€™ll start by simply asking the AI to write a headline for us.
Click here to use my article ğŸ”®
Cut and paste the sample prompt below into the chat box to the right, replacing the placeholder text with the content of your story.






Prompt suggestion



Write a headline for the article below:
(paste the text of the story in)


Press enter or click the send button to ask the chat bot to write the headline.
A prompt is any time you text to a chatbot and ask for a response. Take a moment to think about the chatbotâ€™s response to your prompt. How did it do?


My result was a little more intense than Iâ€™d have liked, but correctly noted the location and one of the major points of conflict in the story:

Bronx Drug Crisis Intensifies Amid Overdose Spike, Highlighting Citywide Dilemma Over Enforcement and Decriminalization.

At first glance this seems great. But should we run right off to publish it?
I find that using generative AI is a lot like going out to eat: even if a result is objectively mediocre, it reflexively seems great since you didnâ€™t have to do the work. It might take some addition effort, but I know we can find some things wrong with it!
No matter how you feel about decriminalization and dramatic headlines, thereâ€™s one thing we can all agree on: this headline is way way way too long.



The greatest strength of AI chatbots like ChatGPT is that they are built around having conversations, and they understand and remember context. That means you can provide feedback and ask follow-up questions, guiding the headline to be closer and closer to what you want.
Unlike many other tasks where you want AI to do the entire job without interruption, headlines are both short enough and important enough that you (probably) want to be fully involved from start to finish!

We commonly use the word â€œcontextâ€ to mean â€œthe subject matter and general gist of a conversation.â€ It actually has a special meaning when it comes to AI! Weâ€™ll talk about it more in a later chapter, but right now itâ€™s the amount of the conversation the AI can remember. If you talk for long enough it will forget the beginning!



Have a conversation with the bot to fix up your headline a bit. Nudge it a few times until you get to something youâ€™re more comfortable with!
Directions to give the chatbot might include revising the length, tone, story angle, and objectivity/emotional appeal.






Prompt suggestions




Revise the headline no more than 10 words
Focus on the inclusion and danger to children
Rewrite the headline in the style of the New York Times
Rewrite the headline as sensationalist, provocative, and punchy



Consider this a tiny, tiny starting point: there are a lot of other aspects you can fool around with.
Ask to make the headline shorter ğŸ”®
Ask for a stronger emotional appeal ğŸ”®
Ask for a less sensational headline ğŸ”®



Notice that my suggested prompts include two different types of tone changes: one asks in the style of a certain publication, while the other includes adjectives specifically describing the tone.
Instead of â€œsensationalist, provocative, and punchyâ€ I could have said â€œin the style of the New York Post.â€ Would that be a more effective shorthand in communicating to the chatbot, or is a specific description more successful? You only know by experimenting!
Also, itâ€™s important to note that I picked those words to describe the New York Post because thatâ€™s how ChatGPT described it when I asked. If you canâ€™t quite put your finger on what makes a certain outlet sound the way it does, ChatGPT is a fantastic resource:

The tone of the New York Post?
The tone of The New York Times?

Although note that ChatGPT doesnâ€™t mention the NYTâ€™s strange relationship to prepositional phrases, so you might still be missing characteristic elements.







After a few rounds of edits, I got tired of making demands of the chatbot and ended up with:

Community Faces Dual Challenge: Drug Use and Public Safety

title: AI Workbook for Journalists
text:
Letâ€™s start from the top again. Instead of just asking for a headline for our story and then spending our time adjusting it, weâ€™ll provide plenty of guidance about what weâ€™re looking for up front.
Figuring out what to ask when youâ€™re looking for a response is called prompt engineering, and itâ€™s often the difference between a successful request and a failed one!
OpenAI, the organization behind ChatGPT, has an entire guide on prompt engineering, full of concrete suggestions. Under â€œWrite clear instructions,â€ they provide the following tips:

Include details in your query to get more relevant answers
Ask the model to adopt a persona
Use delimiters to clearly indicate distinct parts of the input
Specify the steps required to complete a task
Provide examples
Specify the desired length of the output

There are a ton of guides out there to help with your prompting. If you have a little more time I suggest taking a look at Ethan Mollickâ€™s prompting guide, which is a little more conceptual.

When you start to read about how to interact with AI tools like ChatGPT, you start to see the term language model or large language model again and again. Thatâ€™s just the â€œbrainsâ€ of the chatbot, the software that allows it to come up with responses to your requests. Weâ€™ll talk more about the specifics in a later chapter!

text:
Exercise


    


Letâ€™s see if we can get a single prompt that will generate a great headline right out of the gate!
Combine the suggestions above with the directions you nudged the headline in the last exercise to craft a winning request.






A prompt suggestion



You are an editor at the New York Times. Write a headline for the article below. The tone should be informed but approachable. Limit the headline to 70 characters.
ARTICLE:
(paste the story in)


Click here to use my article ğŸ”®
Prompt engineering is a lot like magic: special words you chant to an unknown being that, without rhyme or reason, might cause something amazing to spill forth. It definitely takes practice to get the hang of getting good responses!
Before you get too deep into tweaking the prompt towards a â€œbestâ€ result, you might want to read the next sectionâ€¦

The danger of conversation
One important thing to note is that while context is usually a great thing for ChatGPT to have, a conversation can actually ruin a prompt!
ChatGPT and other AI tools take your entire conversation into account when generating their responses, which can lead to unexpected results:
If youâ€™ve already prompted for a science story about snails and slugs, your headline request for an article about stock prices might be subtlely affected! The AI might cite facts or concepts from the earlier story, or â€œfeelâ€ the unnecessary need to address the middle ground between snails and stocks.
It gets even worse if youâ€™re asking for jokes, poems or dating advice, then pivoting to headline suggestions. Keep to new conversations as much as possible to prevent content pollution and cross-pollination between prompts.
Even computer-y folks miss out on this! A memorable moment was this tweet where someone is kinda dunking on their mom for not using ChatGPT â€œcorrectly:â€



gave my mom access to my ChatGPT account and found out sheâ€™s making new chats for every single prompt & has created over 300 â€œnew chatsâ€ in the past week alone


â€¦and king of LLMs Simon Willison shows up with the facts:



Starting a new chat for each query is a good idea. Itâ€™s only worth reusing an existing chat if youâ€™re asking follow-up questions around the same topic


Good work, mom! So now let me introduce you to a very useful button:
Clear the chat ğŸ”®


The help of suggestions
When you ask an AI tool to do something without providing any examples, this is called a â€œzero shotâ€ approach. Youâ€™re fully relying on the language modelâ€™s understanding of what youâ€™re asking for.
Imagine you had a junior editor you were guiding along, though: youâ€™d probably show them some examples of headlines that worked and headlines that didnâ€™t. You can do the same thing with AI with what is called few-shot prompting. This is what OpenAI means in their guide where they mention â€œProvide examplesâ€ (see above).






A prompt suggestion



You are an editor at the New York Times. Write a headline for the story below. The tone should be informed but approachable. Limit the headline to 70 characters. Donâ€™t use colons or subheads. Move prepositional phrases to the start of the headline.
Good example: On Twitter, Sifting Through Falsehoods in Critical Times
Bad example: Meet the 4 Dem-picked Colorado justices who kicked ex-prez off the ballot
ARTICLE:
(paste the story in)


Click here to use my article ğŸ”®
Clear the chat ğŸ”®
When you get to a prompt you think does a pretty good job, save it. Weâ€™ll make it even better in the next step!


Reflection
Now itâ€™s a bit shorter and the tone has shifted a little bit:

Near Bronx Day Care, Open Drug Market Persists Amid Fentanyl Crisis

I think itâ€™s better, but again: itâ€™s difficult to be critical of something that comes out like magic! But the sharper the eye you can take to it, the more suggestions we can provide in the prompt.
As we had the conversation about our headlines in the last step, you probably noticed a bit of sameness about the headlines. They all seemed to maybe have a similar tone, or a similar angle, or something thatâ€™s justâ€¦ not as varied as when youâ€™d ask a person to generate a handful of headlines.
One downside of having a fine-tuned prompt ready to go is you might just take the first response as the gospel truth: no need to wait for something better, weâ€™ve given it as much guidance as we have! But by only seeing one example, we might not notice the preferences or biases or assumptions that the tool is working with.
Our next step will fix that right up!

title: AI Workbook for Journalists
text:
Next up: we need AI to summarize an article, to write a blurb for social media or the homepage or whatever.
Summarize the article below.

(paste the article in)
OK. We can add some parameters: length, tone, etc.
Summarize the article below. It should sound like the New York Times, informed but approachable. Limit the summary to 70 words.

(paste the article in)
Is that really the NYT tone? Is it actually 70 words? No, but itâ€™s vaguely in the area.
GPT canâ€™t actually count, it doesnâ€™t actually know what the NYT is. But due to the magic of large language models, it kinda works out anyway.






Iâ€™m not 100% joking when I say â€œthe magic of LLMsâ€ â€“ even the people building them are often surprised at how well they perform tasks like these! It doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™re conscious celestial beings, just that complex systems can sometimes have surprising emergent properties.



Article summaries are typically useful for people who are not the author â€“ someone who is writing social posts, or blurbs for homepages or newsletters, or other supporting cases. So instead of cutting and pasting into ChatGPT and having a knowledgeable conversation until it gets just right, youâ€™ll probably want to build it into your CMS workflow or something.
That is called using an API - a way for computers to talk to each other. Your CMS can send the article to OpenAIâ€™s API, get back a summary, and then you can use that summary in your CMS. Easy-peasy route for you to allow other folks to use the tool.
You might have one prompt for the newsletter, one for Twitter posts, one for the homepage. And all these people who are taking on the summary, youâ€™ve just increased their workflow by 100x because they donâ€™t have to actually read the article! And the code to put it together is really easy, itâ€™s just something like:
import openai

# blah blah get the summary
Now you try it. Write a prompt that just works, about an article that you know about.
steal things from the talk
Now: how comfortable would you be letting this automatically generate a summary for you? You know the story in-depth, thatâ€™s fine, you can change it to be what you want. But what about a social media personn, or an editor in charge of a homepage? They might not be familiar, so the fact that the tone is off, or itâ€™s focusing on something that isnâ€™t importantâ€¦ that might be an issue. But thereâ€™s a bigger one.
Play around with this for a little while and youâ€™ll quickly get a summary that is factually incorrect. Not just a different tone, not just a different focus, but wholly incorrect.
You might have heard of hallucinations before, of LLMs getting things wrong. Maybe they donâ€™t know who the current president is, or they make up a book that someone wrote. You might expect this when itâ€™s talking about its giant brain full of infinite knowledge, but it can also happen in a situation as simple as summarizing a short article!
LLMs are a machine that predict the next word. (hungry/starving/famished).
Based on the previous words, it will usually tell you something correct. But GPT doesnâ€™t actually understand anything. It doesnâ€™t understand concepts or ideas or what makes sense or what doesnâ€™t. This is an inherent technical limitation. People are trying their best to engineer around it, but no matter what youâ€™re told by an AI hype person (or well-meaning vendor) incorrect summarizations are absolutely a possibility.
Welcome to the danger zone.
Headline generation is a much easier problem for a few reasons:

Headlines are short so you donâ€™t mind generating a handful to compare
The person requesting the headlines is very familiar with the story, so they can notice if something is off

Writing a longer blurb as a person not closely affiliated with the story gives us many more opportunities for things to go wrong. Not just hallucinations, but tone and angles and a hundred other tiny things.
So how can we deal with that? Maybe the LLM rarely hallucinates, maybe it always does, maybe half the time the tone is wrong? Everyone has a different experience, and someone who is excited about AI is going to let a lot more things slip through and someone who is angry about AI is not going to give it any slack.
The answer to this might be to not use AI, but I have another suggestion: every time you use AI in your newsroom, I want you to track it.
Testing and tracking infrastructure is absolutely necessary when using these tools. How often does it work, how often does it not, and what kinds of errors appear when itâ€™s wrong?
Itâ€™s easy to get enchanted by the fact that AI is doing work for you, and not think about whether itâ€™s actually saving you time or giving you a valuable result. Itâ€™s definitely magic, but sometimes magic isnâ€™t actually useful!
My favorite example is about Danish article summaries, published on The Generative AI Newsroom: https://generative-ai-newsroom.com/summaries-in-danish-with-openai-cbb814a119f2. The author keeps track of every summary, whether it worked, and if it didnâ€™t want the shortcoming was. Look at this piece of beauty:

92 articles were given an accepted summary. 54 of the articles were given an acceptable summary in the first attempt (59%), while the remaining 38 articles took several attempts. A total of 193 summaries were generated, of which 101 summaries were rejected. We didnâ€™t give up on any articles.
The rejected 101 summaries fell into the following categories [number of articles] (number of summaries):

Missing important information [14] (28)
Incorrect summary [14] (23)
AI evaluates content [9] (17) (e.g.Â the model states that the company has had a successful year)
Poor language [9] (12)
Irrelevant information [4] (6)
AI adds own content [2] (7)
Wrong translation [2] (4)
Mentioning what is missing [1] (2) (e.g.Â the model adds: â€œthe company does not provide further information about the reason for the unsatisfactory resultâ€)
AI not aware of public knowledge [1] (1) (the model has limited knowledge of the world and events after 2021, which is evident in the summary. In this case, the model is unaware of a fatal accident that is widely publicized.)
Summary too long [1] (1)


This was instead of saying â€œit feels like magicâ€ or â€œI think I had to click â€˜rengenerateâ€™ a bunchâ€ you get actual metrics to help show you whether the process is working or not.
Once you have those metrics, you have an actionable baseline to know whether itâ€™s worth implementing these tools in your newsroom.
